awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF-RM: The Future of Home Care Work: Designing Technologies for Trust, Privacy, and Empowerment
awd_abstract_narration:
Home health aides are an important group of frontline health workers and one of the fastest-growing sectors of the U.S. workforce. Largely employed by public agencies (Medicare and Medicaid), home health aides currently care for 48 million Americans. However, these workers face numerous challenges as they provide in-home care for people with serious illnesses such as heart failure, diabetes, dementia, and others. Despite spending more time with patients than any other care provider, home health aides, who are mostly women and minorities, are overworked, poorly compensated, and experience high levels of stress and burnout. Their existing tools and technology ecosystems are outdated, hard to use, and largely revolve around monitoring home health aides' labor rather than supporting their work. home health aides find changes in patients' health conditions frightening and struggle to reach supervising clinicians by phone when they need clinical help. Finally, home health aides largely operate day-to-day in isolation, without the ability to be mentored by peers and supervisors, or to grow their skills and advance.
 
This project addresses some of the challenges home health aides face via five complementary research activities that aim to improve the work satisfaction of home health aides, the care received by patients, and the integration of the care team. The first two activities provide new mechanisms for home health aides to obtain care-related information and support by assisting with routine care tasks via multi-modal conversational agents that provide voice-, video-, and text-based guides for completing tasks safely, and providing decision support for clinical questions via a conversational agent that delivers medically-verified information. In parallel, there is a critical need for new mechanisms that enable reliable and timely communication and coordination between home health aides and the rest of the care team. The next two activities engage with this challenge by developing an asynchronous communication tool that connects home health aides directly with clinical staff; and enables data-driven cooperative work and care coordination via new multi-stakeholder and multiple timescale data collection and reporting mechanisms. Taken together, these innovations provide rich opportunities for home health aides to learn and practice new skills, demonstrate their expertise, receive recognition, and meaningfully shape patient care. The final activity creates opportunities for learning and career advancement via new training programs that sustain a sense of progress and advancement while improving patient outcomes. This project, taken as a whole, will improve the skills, well being, and careers of home health aides of the future.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project's major goals were to address challenges faced by home health aides as they deliver essential at-home care that enables older adults and people with chronic conditions to remain at home and age in place. These goals were achieved via several multidisciplinary research arcs that, collectively, transformed current understanding of technology's role in the delivery of home health care, making important knowledge contributions to the fields of computer science, human-computer interaction, medicine, and labor relations.

One major arc of research focused on the design and evaluation of intelligent voice assistants that provide home health aides with on-demand assistance for day-to-day care tasks. For example, one study explored the feasibility and acceptability of using commercially available voice assistants for different kinds of support, including medically oriented task support and emotional support. Another study explored the impact of changing the physical appearance of voice assistants in ways that clearly delineate the devices as work tools to support aides' work in patients' homes. Together, these studies highlight the potential for AI-driven technologies to play important roles in providing vital support and assistance for aides, who often work in isolated conditions with limited access to peers and supervisors.

Another major arc of research aimed to address aides' isolation by developing and deploying computer-mediated peer support programs that are delivered by peer facilitators. Through a series of seminal studies, the research team designed and executed a series of peer support programs, trained peer facilitators to administer the programs, and deployed and evaluated the peer support programs with aides from multiple home care agencies across New York City. These studies showcase how computer-mediated peer support can help to combat aides' isolation, answer questions, build community, and improve job satisfaction. The results of this work have inspired a series of follow-up studies that aim to use this peer support model in new programs that aim to improve aides' physical and mental health.

A third arc of research aimed to elevate and empower aides via new tools that help them advocate for improved working conditions, along with greater recognition and respect for their essential contributions to patient health. For example, we conducted studies that sought to better integrate aides into the broader healthcare team via the design of new communication pathways between aides and supervising clinicians. In another cluster of studies, we explored how aides often perform invisible work that goes unnoticed and unrewarded. In response, we designed and tested new tools that help to make this work more visible, in ways that help aides to advocate for higher wages and improved working conditions.

In addition to the intellectual merits that advanced our fields, this work has had many broader impacts. The project successfully integrated basic research with direct engagement of a range of stakeholder groups, including the home health aides, home care agencies, clinicians, labor unions, and more. The research has resulted in new open-source tools, innovative program designs, procedures, and interventions that are directly helping to improve working conditions for HHAs (a marginalized group of frontline workers), quality of care for patients, and overall care team integration.

Overall, this multidisciplinary project resulted in 16 peer-reviewed publications in top human-computer interaction (HCI), medical, and labor relations venues as well as 2 PhD dissertations. The award also provided numerous training opportunities for students to conduct community-engaged research, write and present research papers, and develop as intellectuals in computing. In particular, the award supported the PhD research of several women and people from underrepresented backgrounds in computing who have since gone on to successful careers in academia. These are excellent outcomes and examples of how engaging young researchers in societally impactful work can help to broaden the participation of women and underrepresented minorities in computing research.
